text:
Izuku Midoriya gets up bright and early on Monday morning, ready to begin the day. He moves about seamlessly, goes through his morning workout without a second thought, then returns to his room without delay. It’s all familiar, these idle motions.


Mindless work, almost, thoughtless in their actions, no reactions to be had. It’s easy work, stressless, the simplicity of a routine known by heart, one Izuku has lived for quite a while.


It gives him time to think.


And that’s what Izuku does, thinking, recalling the conversation from Friday afternoon as he prepares for the day.



“Midoriya.” Aizawa’s normally monotone voice was filled with shock, a shock racing through Izuku’s heart all the same. “Midoriya, did you just use Bakugou’s Quirk?”



Izuku buttons up the white dress shirt, scarred hands shaking only slightly with the motion.



He’s mimicked Kacchan’s Quirk before, of course. Did it so many weeks ago, on the first day of the impersonations, on the first day of the personality swap assignments.



Black dress pants are next, slipped on, the shirt tucked in neatly. 



He made a crude parody of Kacchan’s signature blasts, using One for All to aid him, flicking air in a way that was reminiscent of the boy’s AP shot style.



A dark gray tie comes after, tied in a way that takes thrice the time as Izuku’s normal style. Much more constricting, much more elegant.



He’s mimicked Kacchan’s personality, too. Tried being brash and loud, confident and sure. But being Monoma was different.



Dress shoes get tugged on, tapping against the wooden floor as he shifts around. 



Monoma isn’t Kacchan, Izuku knows that. Anyone would be able to tell, of course. Sure, some may have called both arrogant blonds, and Izuku can agree that both seem to like using insulting nicknames more than they do people’s real names, but that’s where the similarities begin and end. Monoma is less sure, more scared. He’s been viewed as weaker, lesser, because his Quirk is only strong when with others. Alone, Monoma is practically Quirkless.




Alone, Monoma is just like Izuku was. 



Izuku adjusts the cuffs on his sleeves, makes sure that they’re buttoned together. It looks unprofessional, otherwise, he idly notes.


And then he’s lost, back in the fog of his own mind.



Monoma is just like Izuku was, if a little higher up on the totem pole of life. Scared, deemed beneath others, considered powerless despite giving it their all to do all that they could.




Perhaps that’s why Izuku slipped into the role so easily, so fluidly, as if being Monoma was as easy as breathing.



Izuku picks up the final piece of his costume, inspects it. Looks for any grime or grit, anything that could mess up his appearance.



Izuku has always found a way to connect to his character. For Kacchan, it was the familiarity, the past they shared. He had extensive knowledge on his childhood friend’s habits, speaking patterns, and general mannerisms. For Aizawa, he analyzed all that he could, referenced notebook pages with moonlight-aided scribbles from a hand that twitched with excitement and anxiety. Nedzu was his brain, his analysis. Present Mic was his joy, All Might his dreams. Midnight was the confidence he always wanted, Snipe the carefree life he yearned for. Tsukauchi was a dream of a world, if All Might hadn’t changed his mind. Gran Torino was a memory of a week of chaos, of a time spent learning to make One for All his own. Recovery Girl was a different dream, a half-baked one, in which Izuku had promised himself that, if all else failed, he would do his best to help by working in the medical field. Best Jeanist was the man on billboards, a constant presence and source of inspiration, but not an idol. Shinsou was the boy Izuku thinks he would have been, if he were a little more tired and a little less lucky. Shigaraki was an odd parallel, someone who reminded Izuku of a boy he could’ve become, if he were less willing to fix what was broken. Miruko was the shining light Izuku has always hoped to be, the carefree nature that he strives to obtain. Mrs. Joke is the laughter that Izuku hoped to keep, to offer to the world. Hatsume was a different world, one in which Izuku let himself breathe a little easier, and create as a means of being a hero. Hawks embodied the topic of personas in Izuku’s mind, the ability to switch in and out of a character. Even Toga had a connection, if only the urge to put on a mask and act.



He finds nothing.



But Monoma’s feelings were a raw, internal thing, so close yet so far to the boy Izuku used to be. The boy who wanted a chance, who wished so desperately for a Quirk if only so he could belong, so he could 

matter

.




So when Izuku saw Kacchan, when he reached his hand out?



Izuku lifts up the metal brace, slipping it onto his shoulders, sighing as it covers up the majority of his face, leaving only his eyes to peer into the mirror.



He could not help the primal urge to 

want

, to reach out and 

take

.




And a copy formed within his body, and a bang from his very fingertips.




“Yes.”



Izuku looks away, feeling far more tired than before.


Yes, Izuku Midoriya had used Explosion, because he had used Copy...because he had used something else, something Izuku never thought that he would have, not for himself.


Not like this.


But Izuku Midoriya had a Quirk.


And now it is up to him to figure out what it did.


-----


It’s a beautiful Monday morning, just like most others, if perhaps a little cooler than the one before. The weather is changing, the seasons going, and there are only a few weeks remaining in the second term. While this does guarantee the approach of term finals, it also offers a reprieve in the form of winter break, a time that the students of 1-A cannot help but look forward to.


But this is not where their minds are, not today. No, today their thoughts are elsewhere, in another place.


Another time, to be more precise, and it is the same time for each student sitting at their desk.


Friday afternoon. 


Because no one quite understands what happened that Friday afternoon. Most of them were busy sparring against their own opponents, the majority did not see what had occurred. All that they remember is an especially jarring explosion, and then a silence from that vicinity. They can recall assuming that Bakugou or Monoma had simply used too much power, that Kirishima or Midoriya had been 

hurt

, and stopping in their motions to check on the two.


Only to find Aizawa leading a shaking Midoriya away, his teammate and opponents staring after him with perplexed expressions.


Only to hear that it had been Midoriya who had let loose the explosion, not the one to receive it.


And that….that is intriguing, and confusing, because there is no talk of gear from Hatsume, no explanation for how such a feat is possible without a Quirk.


Unless there 

is

 a Quirk.


And the students of 1-A are curious, of course, and they want to know more. But...


But Midoriya had looked panicked, whenever someone brought up the incident. His eyes would water and his shoulders would shake, and that was more than enough to get whoever was curious to stop asking. Conversations would be shifted, new topics transitioned to in the blink of an eye.


And now it is Monday, and the students of 1-A are as clueless as they had been that Friday afternoon. But they will not pester Midoriya for answers, not when it clearly hurts him so to think of the moment. No, they will just treat him as they always have, as their friend Midoriya and nothing more.


This plan is halted the moment the bell rings. Because with the bell comes Aizawa, and with Aizawa comes Midoriya.


And Midoriya isn't dressed as himself.


Dress shoes click against tiled floors, perfectly pressed pants show no creases and a perfectly done shirt and tie have no wrinkles or odd folds. A metal brace rests upon his neck, covering the bottom of his face.


And doing nothing to hide the dismissive yet assessing gaze that Midoriya sends their way.


Midoriya stands motionless at the front, hands clasped behind his back and head tilted in a way that shows deference to Aizawa, and yet allows him to continue his sweep of the room. It is a gaze both piercing yet dull, and all the more unsettling thanks to this odd duality.


And the students of 1-A cannot help but be surprised that Aizawa chose to give Midoriya an assignment, but they are more surprised by 

who

 Aizawa has chosen for their peer.


"I have been tasked with watching over Kurogiri for the day. If anything happens, inform me immediately," Aizawa warns, and the class reels back in shock.


A villain. Izuku Midoriya has been set to play a villain, even after Friday's events.


But they do not complain, partially because they know their classmate, and know that he would not do an assignment if he was uncomfortable. He has promised to do so, and Midoriya hates breaking promises.


The other part is fueled, however, by the way that a single glance from the current Midoriya is enough to send shivers up the sign of his peers. Perhaps it is not the best time to speak out.


Perhaps not, indeed.


And so Monday begins with confusion, wonders, and worries.


(Well placed worries, not that they will be truly noted as such.)


(Not until later.)


-----


Hizashi Yamada isn’t quite sure what he was expecting out of today, but it sure wasn’t, well, 

this

.


This, of course, being the way that the class seems to evade Izuku Midoriya’s space, the boy exuding a rather...eerie aura as he sits calmly in his seat. 


The boy’s apparel is far more formal than usual, and as much as Hizashi isn’t surprised that Shouta went for a new swap today- even with the rumors of Friday’s occurrence running through the halls- he is surprised but how...silent today’s swap is.


And Hizashi cannot help but be unnerved by the sheer lack of reaction from Midoriya, by the way that the boy simply stares straight ahead, watching Hizashi with an empty gaze. The rest of 1-A, Hizashi can tell, are just as affected, as much as some try to hide this fact. 


It’s something about how little Midoriya moves, the lack of a reaction to the actions that go on around him. His hands stay still no matter what Hizashi says, the boy never reaching for his pencil nor his notebook. His eyes only move when someone says the name 

Kurogiri

, the only sign of who Midoriya is supposed to be past the brace that rests on his face and covers the bottom half of his face. There is no reaction otherwise, no words spoken, nothing uttered even once.


And this is rather...odd, as Kurogiri spoke before, has been reported to have spoken during the U.S.J. attack when declaring the intentions of the League to this very class, has had witnesses recall how he was the one to reveal Shigaraki’s name when conversing with the man.


Yet here? Here, Midoriya remains silent, simply watching and waiting.


But Hizashi isn’t sure what Midoriya is waiting for, and that’s one of the worst parts of it all.


And for a moment, Hizashi cannot help but look into Midoriya’s eyes and think of them as lifeless, like the light in them is only a forcefully created illusion to hide the decay behind the source.


But Kurogiri is alive, Hizashi knows, and so he brushes the thought aside, lets himself believe that he is merely overthinking Midoriya’s acting as he has before.


And yet when Midoriya’s eyes flash yellow, even if only for a moment… this time, Hizashi lets the image stay in his mind.


He won’t turn a blind eye to such an instance, not anymore. 


Not after Friday.


(Because a part of Hizashi wonders how many little moments have happened, how much sooner they all could have realized that Midoriya’s acting was more than just the hobby, that it was something ingrained in the boy without the greenet’s knowledge.)


(Wonders if it would have made a difference, and how.)


(And later on, Hizashi will wonder if catching the Quirk’s appearance earlier would have changed the outcome of today...but that is for another day.)


-----


The bell for lunch rings, and nineteen of the twenty students of 1-A are up and out of the classroom mere moments after, all ready to head to the cafeteria.


The final student stays still, perfectly poised in his seat. 


Well, that's almost correct. Izuku Midoriya does, in fact, move, but only to reach out and grab his lunch, and then to eat. The motions are simple, efficient, precise.


He stops moving the moment he is done, empty containers packed away and nowhere to be found. He sits in his chair, stares straight ahead, and if anyone were to glance in, they would note how even Midoriya’s breathing is minimal.


But no one glances into the room, because they are all too wary of the character Midoriya has become.


A shame, truly, for it means missing how Midoriya acts as if he is nothing more than an NPC awaiting an order.


Perhaps, if only one person had looked his way, they would've noticed that Midoriya does not move without a goal, that Midoriya acts under predetermined commands that only he knows of.


Perhaps it would have reminded them of another creature, one first seen at the U.S.J., and the story of tomorrow would not have come as such a shock.


But no one sees, and the story of tomorrow has not yet come, and so Midoriya remains frozen until the period ends, and the day goes on.


And life continues.


-----


Toshinori Yagi has had mixed feelings about young Midoriya’s personality swapping assignments from the very beginning. He was terrified at first, scared by the boy’s ability to switch his act so smoothly, to be so jarringly different from his normal character. 


Terror changed, however, becoming a calm acceptance to an earnest enjoyment of the boy’s displays, even if Toshinori found himself terrified from time to time thanks to Aizawa’s targeted choices. The swaps were nice, a chance for his successor to shine and stand out, for the world to see the potential that Toshinori had all those months ago. It was a chance for the boy to be himself, for Midoriya to see how much more he was than he had initially believed. 


It was a piece of Midoriya untouched by a Quirk, the boy’s brain and talent shining through, nothing that Midoriya couldn’t have done while Quirkless. It was just Midoriya, and always had been.


But then it wasn’t, as revealed by a sudden explosion that originated from his successor. An explosion that sparked a flurry of reveals, of understandings, of brushed aside ‘beliefs’ being noted as perhaps something more.


Young Midoriya had a Quirk, and had absolutely no clue. That much was clear by the way that he had reacted, by the talk the two had had over the weekend.


A heartbreaking one, at that.

“I...I can give you One for All back,” Midoriya promised, with shaking hands and teary eyes. “I didn’t- I didn’t know, I didn’t mean to trick you, I-”


“I know,” Toshinori said, and he meant it because he 

did

. “But the Quirk is not one that I want back. It’s 

yours

, kid.”




“But I have-”




“And now you have another,” Toshinori cut in. “And we will work on this, to help you master them both, until you feel confident enough to see that they both belong to you, and always will.”



He had been so frightened, so lost, and yet his first thought was on giving up One for All...Toshinori shakes his head, forces the memories aside. As much as he wants to ponder over this revelation, as much as they all want to, he knows that he must teach.


Still, he cannot help but let his thoughts stray to his boy the moment Midoriya and his peers are on the training field.


Because it appears that Midoriya is still doing his acting assignments.


And for a moment, Toshinori cannot help but wonder 

why

 Aizawa would choose to do such a thing, and then he realizes that the man is likely trying to figure out the Quirk as well. Its features are unclear, after all, and no one is quite sure why it has activated when it did, just that it is tied to Midoriya’s acting. It makes sense, then, to have Midoriya act during hero training, and the rest of the day, as well, in order to give the boy the chance to try unlocking his Quirk yet again.


Still, Toshinori cannot help but find a bit of him rather...uneasy, with such a thing. Especially when Midoriya is set to be Kurogiri, one of the League of Villains main, well, villains.


But perhaps that is simply because Midoriya’s Quirk seems to be working, albeit oddly. 


Worryingly.


Toshinori sends the students to their own individual spots, separated far away from one another in order to work on their Quirks and special moves, leaving Midoriya in a corner of his own, with more distance from the rest for safety’s sake.


And Midoriya….doesn’t do much. Not at first, at least. He just stands there, eyes barely moving, unshining.


But then something seems to change, and his eyes begin to sweep over the room, searching, flickering yellow at random.


And then something shifts, and so does Midoriya, an arm reaching out, hand opening slowly.


Mist begins to surround him. Dark purple wisps dance up and down his arms, matching portals of shadow opening wide, leading to who knows where. Midoriya tilts his head, opens one wider, snaps it shut.


Five more form in an instant, small and misshapen but most definitely there. 


No one is working anymore. They haven’t been since the first wisps of fog began to cover the boy, but now they all just watch and wait, keep their eyes on the boy whose eyes are eerily empty.


Toshinori can’t find it in himself to correct them. He’s too busy doing the exact same thing, watching his boy do something that he never would have thought possible.


The wisps of fog grow in size, denser than before. It is harder to see Midoriya’s arms underneath the misty purple expanse, but Midoriya does not show even the slightest bit of concern. It is as if he has grown desensitized to the fog, as if it isn’t unusual in the slightest.


A portal grows wider in front of Midoriya, and the boy steps within it without a moment of hesitation, earning startled gasps from his peers. But Midoriya appears seconds later, halfway across the gym, right beside Bakugou. The action startles the blond, but Bakugou does his best to hide the way he stiffens at Midoriya’s sudden closeness.


It does little to change how Midoriya locks eyes with Bakugou, head tilting a mere fraction as he studies his peer.


The only one who had ever been dragged through Kurogiri’s portals during the summer camp.


Another portal opens, and Bakugou takes a step back, fists raising. Midoriya stares at him, then moves back into the portal. 


There is clear relief when the portal snaps shut, and Midoriya ends up across the room once more, and Toshinori cannot help but notice how Bakugou tracks Midoriya more intensely than before.


Midoriya flits around a few more times, stepping from portal to portal, from one corner of the room to the next, and then he pauses in the center of the room. Bright yellow eyes flick around, and then both hands reach out, palms out and far reaching.


And then he makes a wide, sweeping gesture, and dozens of portals form. Some large, some small, but all scattered throughout the space.


All placed exactly where Midoriya had already been, down to the flickering wisps that encompass the edges.


Arms stretch out wider, fingers splayed, and the portals grow darker and wider. Those nearby stumble backwards, and Toshinori feels the urge to call upon the Quirk he’s long since said farewell to.


But then, like an act of mercy, the bell rings, the portals snap shut, and Midoriya moves with a gait both fluid and stilted, as if the boy is detached and unaware of his own movements, simply following a code that is built into his head.


The fog does not disappear from his arms. In fact, it only creeps further along his body.


Toshinori cannot wait for the day to end; he wants to see the life return to Midoriya’s eyes as soon as possible.


(He’ll get his wish, but not in the way that he expected.)


-----


It's nearing the end of the day, and the students of 1-A cannot help but be grateful for such a fact.


Because there are less than ten minutes on the clock, less than ten minutes before the bell rings and school is over, which means that there are less than ten minutes until Izuku Midoriya goes back to being himself.


The students of 1-A, at the end of the day, like the personality swap assignments that have filled their days with excitement and anticipation. When all is said and done, the class cannot help but look forward to who Midoriya will be next, cannot help but wonder how Midoriya will raise the bar for his own talent once more.


But all is not said nor done, and Midoriya is covered in that purple fog that has only grown since hero training, and so 1-A waits impatiently for the day to end, so that Midoriya will become Midoriya once more.


Even Aizawa seems affected, today, which makes sense. Midoriya has never been like 

this

, slowly encompassed by a fog of his own creation. It looks as if Kurogiri is trying to take the boy away, or perhaps take him over, and the students of 1-A would not be surprised if Aizawa is thinking of their encounters with the man of mist.


They are, too, after all. Times when Midoriya was far too close to portals, when they all were. The fear that they had felt, the way they had to save themselves. They had been nothing but panicked determination, wild eyed and worried.


But here sits Midoriya, swallowed by the fog that once sent him crashing underwater, and yet his eyes are blank, posture poised yet serene, an artificial peace.


His eyes are one of the only visible parts of him, shining bright beneath the mist, but no one makes a comment. Not when they are so close to it all going away.


And then, with just two minutes left on the bell, things change.


The classroom door is pushed open, and two people walk in. The first is Yamada, someone familiar, recognizable. The second is much smaller, a little girl with shining red eyes and white hair, one that it takes 1-A a few seconds to remember.


Eri, the girl Midoriya saved not so long ago. Who looks up to Midoriya as if he personally set the stars and sun into the sky just for her, as if he is the brightest star of all. She looks up to him the way 1-A might their own idols, or siblings, or perhaps even both.


And now, Eri is looking at Midoriya, mist-covered, yellow-eyed Midoriya, with the same unabashed admiration as always.


“Sorry, she didn’t want to wait,” Yamada explains, but everyone is more focused on how Eri races right to Midoriya, arms reaching out and wrapping around the boy’s legs just as he stands up, undoubtedly about to break character. The purple fog dances around the boy, then begins to dim, fading.


But then Eri, in her joy, squeezes Midoriya’s legs tighter and laughs excitedly, horn sparking with her joy, a sign of Quirk activation.


And Midoriya collapses.


And everything goes wrong.


-----


A part of Shouta knew from the moment Izuku Midoriya walked into class this morning that today was a bad idea. There was something eerie in the way that Midoriya’s gaze had gone blank, something worrying in how little the boy seemed to register the world around him. His plans seemed to swap immediately, going from something good to something worth keeping a wary, watchful eye on.


A part of Shouta 

knew

, and yet he let it continue. Because he is Midoriya’s teacher, and teachers are meant to help their students grow. Shouta knows that Midoriya’s previous teachers failed miserably at this task, and so he refused to let his own doubts interfere with Midoriya’s growth.


Because with the activation of Midoriya’s Quirk- of a Quirk Midoriya clearly never knew he had- Shouta knew that Midoriya would need help 

training 

it, would need to learn how to activate it and how much it could do. Shouta knew that past instances that he had brushed aside as tricks of the light or similar ideas were the beginnings of his Quirk awakening, and knew that Midoriya could do so much more- a surprising yet unsurprising notion for the boy- than before.


And Kurogiri was chosen on 

purpose

. Kurogiri wasn't a pick left to chance, he was carefully studied and decided on. Because Kurogiri 

should have been safe

. His Quirk gave him portals, nothing more. His Quirk wasn't naturally dangerous, not like touches that lead to decay or the ability to wield explosions. It was just 

portals

, and Midoriya should have been 

safe

.


He never factored in Eri, or how Midoriya’s Quirk would react to new situations. He never considered the idea that Midoriya could just...collapse.


But one touch from a Quirk-using Eri and Midoriya was dropping, and suddenly Shouta found his life blurring, nothing important except grabbing his kid and getting him to Recovery Girl.


And that's where they've been, since. It's been at least an hour, maybe more, but Shouta has yet to stray from his student's side. Hizashi dismissed the kids back to the dorms, Shouta thinks, but he can't get himself to go and check. He just can't bring himself to leave Midoriya’s side, to risk missing the moment when Midoriya wakes up.


He just needs his kid to wake up, to prove that he's alright. Until then, Shouta will sit right here and wait.


And Shouta waits, and waits, and it takes until the middle of the night but Midoriya wakes up, and Shouta is relieved.


And then he is not, because when he locks eyes with his kid, it is not green eyes that peer back at him.


No, Shouta locks eyes with ones that are a bright, clear blue, and one realization comes to mind.


Midoriya may not be Kurogiri anymore...but Shouta isn’t looking at Midoriya, not right now.


(Something is terribly wrong.)


Bright blue eyes stare into Shouta’s own, and they watch him in a way that makes Shouta feel like he’s being analyzed for all that he’s worth. 


And right now, he can’t say for certain that that’s very much at all.


But those eyes keep staring, searching, looking for 

something

 and Shouta just doesn’t know what it is. It must be found, though, because those blue eyes light up, quite literally, shining in the dark for just a moment before glancing away, wandering the empty room. Recovery Girl’s office is odd, eerie, leaving Shouta with shivers down his spine in the moonlit area.


Or maybe the feeling comes from the calm emanating from his student, from his student who should have green eyes and a cheerful smile, now much more passive in the midnight hour.


Shouta looks away, unable to make eye contact any longer. He glances out the window, sees the moon shining high and the stars dancing in the darkened sky. It’s calm, serene, outside of the room that Shouta resides in. 


Shouta doesn’t feel very calm, but he looks back to his student nonetheless. Because this is his student, and he doesn’t know what is happening, just that things are not as they 

should

 be, and it is up to Shouta to make things right.


But when Shouta looks back, it is to eyes already shut and soft breathing to match.


Izuku Midoriya is asleep once more, and Shouta is more stressed than he was just moments before.


He can only hope that Midoriya will be his usual self when he wakes again.


-----


Midoriya is not his usual self, and Shouta Aizawa feels like a fool for expecting anything else.


He fell asleep, too, at some point. Between one moment of worries and another of trying to come up with solutions, Shouta must have drifted off, too overwhelmed and helpless to prevent the call of sleep from claiming him. Not that it helped, no, he still feels like he’s in a waking nightmare from the moment that he opens his eyes.


Because Midoriya is up and awake, and he is moving about. But it is not with the familiarity that Midoriya usually does, having been in the nurse’s office so many times at the beginning of the year, but a sort of wonder, as if seeing something that he has not in quite some time.


Quite some time, indeed, if Midoriya’s comments are to be accounted for.


“That wasn’t there last time,” Midoriya murmurs, eyeing a machine that Shouta can recall having been bought the year after he started working here.


“Oh, it seems they replaced the old cot. And here I thought that third year with the metal Quirk would get to have a legacy within Yuuei!” 


Shouta can’t recall there being a third year with a metal Quirk this year.


“Woah! Those are a 

lot

 of new buildings! They must have done some renovations, eh, Shou?” Bright blue eyes glance his way, and Shouta stares back. Midoriya doesn’t look at him for long, though, pushing open the window to look at some of the dorms. “Wow. I knew Yuuei worked fast, but this is 

incredible

. Gee, I wonder what else they may have done!”


And then Midoriya is turning and walking out of the room, leaving Shouta to race after him. The boy’s head turns this way and that, as if confused by his surroundings, and yet Midoriya is able to make his way through the school all the same.


“Wait, are these 

dorms

?” Midoriya asks, glancing at Shouta. “That sounds like fun, I wonder why they decided to put them in, though.” Midoriya reaches a hand up, as if going to tap at his chin, only for it to bump into the metal brace that Shouta hadn’t been able to get off of his student, too afraid to jostle his kid around in his sleep and risk any more problems. The brace seems to startle Midoriya, though, and his eyebrows furrow as his fingers curl around the edges of it before yanking it off.


“Why was I wearing this?” Midoriya murmurs, and then glances at his outfit. “What am I, a bartender or something?” He snorts at his own joke, and then turns to Shouta. “Hey, is there anywhere I can swap my clothes?”


Shouta clears his throat, pushes past the feeling that screams that Midoriya is acting far too familiar right now, that there’s a few missing pieces to the puzzle that he’s been forcefully given and that they need to click into place for Shouta to finally 

understand

, and nods. “Follow me,” Shouta says, and then he leads Midoriya to Heights Alliance.


The dorms are silent, when Shouta enters them. No one is up, not a soul is to be seen. It’s early, Shouta knows, but another part wonders if his students are just afraid to get up, to realize that Midoriya isn’t in his dorm sleeping peacefully, or outside doing his morning workout as he normally does.


He can’t blame them, not when that pervasive feeling of 

wrong

 lingers in his heart as he leads Midoriya to his own room, the boy looking mystified with every turn, as if nothing is familiar anymore.



What happened to his kid?
